description.en: Introduction to the topic; general linguistic and typological perspectives on the topic; Uralistic perspectives and problems; reading; text work; home work; summary.
description.et: Sissejuhatus teemasse; üldkeeleteaduslik ja tüpoloogiline lähenemine teemale; Uralistika vaatenurgad ja probleemid; lugemine; töö tekstiga; kodutöö; kokkuvõte.

objectives.en: Examination of linguistic structures in typological and Uralistic perspective on a descriptive, comparative, and historical base.
objectives.et: Keelestruktuuride uurimine tüpoloogia ja Uralistika vaatenurgast deskriptiivsel, võrdleval ja ajaloolisel alusel.

learning_outcomes.en: At the end of seminar students have read and discussed several articles on the present topic to get acquainted with linguistic theory and advances in Uralic grammar writing; they have actively worked with texts from different Uralic languages in order to develop their skills in analyzing and adequately describing linguistic structures as well as their philological skills; and they have written a home work in order to develop their academic writing skills.
learning_outcomes.et: Seminari lõpuks on üliõpilased lugenud ja läbi arutanud mitmeid artikleid käsitletaval teemal, et tutvuda Uurali keelte grammatikakirjelduse alase keeleteooriaga ja viimaste arengutega selles vallas; nad on aktiivselt töötanud tekstidega erinevates Uurali keeltes, et arendada oma keelestruktuuride analüüsimise ja kirjeldamise oskust ning filoloogilisi oskusi; nad on kirjutanud kodutöö, et arendada oma akadeemilise kirjutamise oskust.

notes.en:
The topic in spring 2025 is QUESTIONS. The course Comparative Grammar of Uralic Languages will focus on form, meaning, and pragmatics of questions across Uralic languages from the typological perspective. We will discuss the ways Uralic languages express canonical (information-seeking) and non-canonical (biased, rhetorical, reflective, echo-) questions. We want to find out how questions of different structural types (polar, constituent, disjunctive) are formed, explore the taxonomy of interrogative words, and talk about wh-in-situ languages. We’ll also discuss question-answer pairs and response words in Uralic languages and beyond.

To get the gist of some features we’ll be looking at, we advise participants to get familiar with the following chapter: Aikhenvald, Alexandra Yu. 2014. Sentence types. In Jan Nuyts & Johan van der Auwera (eds.), The Oxford handbook of Mood and Modality, 141165. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

As the outcome of the course, the students are required to compile a typological questionnaire based on which a grammar chapter about questions in a particular Uralic language could be written.
